metadata.title: How to embed security in your Azure Data Science Project | by René Bremer | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to embed security in your Azure Data Science Project
metadata.description: A lot of companies struggle to bring their data science projects into production. In the previous blog, it was discussed how to setup a build/release pipeline for data science projects. This enables…

all_paragraphs: A lot of companies struggle to bring their data science projects into production. In the previous blog, it was discussed how to setup a build/release pipeline for data science projects. This enables a company to 1) trace a model end to end, 2) build trust in a model and so to 3) avoid situations in which predictions of a model are inexplicable.
In every build/release pipeline, security is an important topic. Common security aspects are the following:
Update September 17, 2020: Blog and gitrepo that is specific for this blog is not maintained and cannot be used 1 to 1. Ideas are still valid, though. For a working example, see my previous blog

In this tutorial, a build/release pipeline for a machine learning model is created that predicts the income class of a person. In this, a model is constructed Azure Databricks and the model is then deployed in a Web App that functions as HTTPS endpoint. The following security aspects are incorporated in the build/release pipeline:
This can be depicted in the following architecture overview:
In the remainder of this blog, the following steps will be executed:

It is a standalone tutorial, however, the focus will now be on security and less on the machine learning model. In case you are more interested in ML, it is recommended to do the previous blogs, here or using scikit-learn, see here.
The following resources need to be created in the same resource group and in the same location.
The following steps will be executed in this part. Notice that Azure CLI is used whenever possible.
In this step, the keys of the storage accounts are added to the key vault using the Azure CLI. Copy keys as follows:

Now add the storage account name and storage account key to the Azure key vault using the following code. It is recommended to use the same bold names through the entire tutorial, since this names are used as variables in the Azure DevOps build step. Make sure that the user that was used to log into the Azure CLI has enough rights to create/list/get keys in the key vault.

Create an Azure Key Vault-backed secret scope in Databricks. This enables to store your secrets in a key vault and keys do not have to be stored in a notebook anymore. Name the secret scope as: devaisec
Download the datafile from https://amldockerdatasets.azureedge.net/AdultCensusIncome.csv on your pc. Then add data to storage container as follows:

This step is only possible if you deployed your Databricks workspace in your own VNET, see here. Go to your storage account, select firewalls and then add the VNET in which you deployed your Databricks workspace.
Make sure that both the private and public subnets of the Databricks VNET are added to the firewall of the storage account.
Go to your Azure Databricks workspace, right-click and then select import. In the radio button, select to import the following notebook using URL:
Replace the following variables with you own variables
Make sure that a cluster is running to which the notebook can be attached. A cluster can be created using the default settings. Then run notebook to create the ML model.
Azure DevOps is the tool to continuously build, test, and deploy your code to any platform and cloud. The following needs to be done:
A token is needed to programatically access Azure Databricks. Go to Azure Databricks and click to the person icon in the upper right corner. Select User Settings and then generate a new token.
Again, add the key to the Azure key vault:
Also, add the value of your subscription_id to the key vault.
The Personal Access Token will be rollovered as part of the build pipeline.
Create a new Azure DevOps project following this link. Once you create a new project, click on the repository folder and select to import the following repository:
A Service connection is needed to access the resources in the recourse group from VSTS. Go to project settings, service connection and then select Azure Resource Manager.
Select Service Principal Authentication and limit scope to your resource group. Name the connection as devopsaisec_service_connection

To configure key rollover from the Azure DevOps pipeline, the service principal needs to have set access rights on the Azure key vault. Therefore, look up the application id of the service connection by clicking on the service connection and then select “Update service connection” and then click on the link “ use the full version of the service connection dialog”.
Finally, give the service principal set rights on secrets in key vault (service connection already has get and list rights).
In step 4a, the storage keys were added to the Azure Key vault. Subsequently, Databricks access token and subscription_id were added in step 5a.

Our Azure DevOps project needs these secrets. Therefore, click on libraries and choose to link secrets in Azure Key Vault to project. Select the service connection that was created in step 5b and the key vault where the secrets are stored and click on authorize.
Finally, add the secret variables “dbr-key”, “dbr-token and “subscription-id” to the project and click save.

Apart from secret variables, there are also other configuration needed for the Azure DevOps project to function. Again, go to libraries, allow access to all pipelines and add the following variables with your own values as group:

In this step, the build pipeline is created. Click on “Pipelines”, select “New” and then “New build pipeline”. Keep the defaults and click on “Continue”. In the next screen, select “Configuration as code” and click on “Apply”.
Select as Agent Pool to have a “hosted Ubuntu 1604” and select as filepath: project/configcode_build_sec.yml. Then click save, see also screen below

Finally, link the secret variable group that is created earlier. Therefore, click on Variables groups, link both the secret variables groups created in 5d and the other variables group in 5e and click on Save & queue to start the build.
After run is succesfully executed, you can see the build, first running and the end result.
In this build pipeline, the following steps are executed:
The next part is about creating a release pipeline. In this, it deploys the Machine Learning Model as a Container on a web app.
To achieve complete network isolation to your web app, an App Service Environment shall be used. All web apps and app service plans that are deployed in an App Service Env.

Notice that an App Service Environment can be costly. The remaining of the tutorial can also be done with web apps that are not deployed in a private ASE, however, the web app will then have a public IP.
Execute the following command lines to create an Azure web in linux.
In this step, the container is deployed to the web app. Go to “Pipelines”, select “Releases” and then select as template “empty job”. Changes the names and then click save.
Add an artifact which you would like to release in this pipeline. In this case select the artifact created from the build pipeline. Make sure that you always select as Default version: Latest

Finally, add the two variable groups (that were created in step 5c and 5d) also to the release pipeline. Go to variables in your release pipeline and link both group, similar as was done in the build pipeline.
Go to the release pipeline and choose to add a task. You will then see a screen with an agent job. Again, you need to change the Agent Pool to Hosted Ubuntu 1604.

Subsequenty, add a new task by searching for Azure CLI. Select devopsaisec_service_connection as service connection and refer to “41_deployImageToWebapp_sec.sh” as script path. Then use the following 3 arguments separated by a space: name of your webapp, name of your container registry and name of resource group by referring to the variable $(rg-name).

Save and close and select to create a release pipeline. Fill in the variables to create the release. Then deploy the release by clicking on the deploy button. Wait 5 minutes and then check that the status changed from “Not deployed” to Succeeded”.

In this step Azure Active Directory Authentication is enables in the web app using the Azure Portal. Go to your web app, select Authentication/ Authorization and then Azure Active Directory. Then select Express and to a create a new app registration using the same name as your web app
After this step, the web app URL requires authentication and cannot be consumed.
Final step is to setup tool Postman to authenticate to web app. In this tutorial below it is explained how this can be done.

After you setup Postman and the client authentication in Postman to the web app, the HTTPS endpoint can be consumed to create predictions. An example payload can be found in the project/services/50_testEndpoint.py in the project. In this example, the income class of three persons is predicted.

In this tutorial, a secure end to end pipeline for a machine learning project is created. In this, Azure Databricks was used to create a machine learning model and deployed this as an endpoint on a web app. The end to end pipeline was secured as follows:

This enables a company to 1) trace a model end to end, 2) build trust in a model 3) avoid situations in which predictions of a model are inexplicable and above all 4) secure data, endpoints and secrets using AAD, VNETs and Key vaults, see also the architecture overview:

Note from Towards Data Science’s editors: While we allow independent authors to publish articles in accordance with our rules and guidelines, we do not endorse each author’s contribution. You should not rely on an author’s works without seeking professional advice. See our Reader Terms for details.
Data Solution Architect @ Microsoft, working with Azure services as ADFv2, ADLSgen2, Azure DevOps, Databricks, Function Apps and SQL. Opinions here are mine.
